Liz, I am not sure we will be able to get a response to this before Monday. How urgent is it?
It would be really good to get sorted – there are quite a few of timely photos we’d like to get up. Could it be a priority for the remainder of the day?

Liz,

Looking at http://gettyftp.kitsite.com/images.php, I don't see anything waiting to go, as described by Justin yesterday.

Could you (or somebody) re-submit any images that apparently didn't make it through in the usual way and then let us know that you have done so and confirm that they have turned up at gettyftp.kitsite.com. We can then have a look and try to work out what the problem is.

It would also be useful to know what the images were that didn't make it through yesterday.

None of the code been touched on our end for some time, so I am a bit mystified as to what the problem might be (other than Jamie's suggestion that the image might have been missing).

Justin, do you mind re-sending one of the Getty pics? And could you reply-all to this and tell us the name of some of the pics you already tried to send through?

Cheers,

Liz

Hi all. Justin's just sent some more images through as I said to Danny on the phone:


http://mm.gettyimages.com/mm/nicePath/locog?nav=pr147450472 – Link to images in Getty MM

http://gettyftp.kitsite.com/images.php - images showing as waiting to go to web
Any news on this folks. We've had more images come through today so it's odd that the CGIs don't work.

Hi Finn,

It's the 'Â©Te' at the start of <gyi:value name='Filename'>Â©Team_Populous_2012Greenwich[1].jpg</gyi:value>

Any chance you could rename and resend.

btw. there was talk, many moon ago :) of Getty exposing a proper web API so we can dump the current feed and FTP servers and switch to a proper web service, that would make so much easier as Getty could just poll us when they had new images, we could then fetch that image and if there was any issues automatically email the relevant people. What we have currently is a bit string and tape, as Getty FTP an XML file and hopefully an image to an intermediate FTP sever, we then try and pick up those XML files and look for the images referenced in the XML file, which sometimes haven't made it across to the FTP server or have otherwise been corrupted.

Still doesn’t seem to be working I’m afraid Jamie, another picture didn’t come through last night. This is from Justin:


I have sent through the image filenames below. they are showing here http://gettyftp.kitsite.com/images.php but they are not getting to the web. Please note the first 3 images on the link are the CGI’s with the filenames with bad characters that I have adjusted and they can be seen further down the list.

AE4Q0094
Greenwich_CGI_Team_Populous_2012
Broxbourne_CGI_Team_Populous_2012
Lords_CGI_Team_Populous_2012
Horse_Guards_Parade_TEAM_POPULOUS_2012
Can we please treat this as top priority until it is fixed? Jamie, if you are struggling to find images, or need more to be sent through, I recommend you call Justin directly to re-send.

Liz just so I am clear, are you saying *no* images are coming across?

They seem to be appearing here?
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/data/Photo%20pages

Maybe Justin isn't aware that there is a delay in sending the image out of Getty and arriving in the CSM? From the very start we suggested using a web service to handle this process (for thsi and other reasons) but I think Getty only got as far as saying one might be built in future.

There have been two real issues with the Getty feed this year that I am aware of:

1) Bad characters, this /isn't/ just a case of non alphanumeric chars rather what looks like computer generated data characters at the start of the title (even if we could deal with these, it would be unwise to bring them into the CMS)
2) An old (and reported issue) with Media Manager whereby if you chose the wrong target or send an image in a slightly different way in Media Manger (I never understood the *exact* reasons) we only get the CML file and not the image. As far as I am aware this is not a recurring issue and if images are sent in the way Justin seems to be sending them then there shouldn't be an issue.

If there is a wider issue, then we need to trace though the images from Getty (checking how they are sent; as I said I don't know the correct way; I just know one way previously caused the XML to be sent without the JPG) though the FTP server and into the CMS. It would be good if this is the case to set aside an hour where we can run though this process in real time and check the image at each step of the way.
Yep, they seem to have come through, you’re right

Oops, trigger happy with the send button then.

I’ll talk to Justin about the delay...

Righty, they’re definitely in CMS as you say. I think Justin’s confusion is that they’re not appearing in the Latest Photos feed: http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php . Are they supposed to automatically publish to that?
They are – but it actually depends on the time stamp. Is it possible that they are stamped with either: no date or a date awhile in the past??

Ah well spotted Liz !!

That would be it

Apparently Justin says that the date field specifically is getting lost from the Getty ‘created date’ in the CMS. It’s not ideal – could you take a look and see if there’s any obvious reason why the date would be getting stripped out?

Liz,

There is a date field called 'post date' which is the only that one is used (as it was considered the editorial date, in case you want to 'fake' the date that appears on a given photo)

Is that the one that is being used? Hard to tell as I can't see any files on the FTP server or else I'd check myself.

thanks

Jamie

Is ‘post date’ a kitsite field, or the field you are looking for from Getty? Justin can manually add dates in the CMS, his concern is that the date he is entering into Getty isn’t making it into the Kitsite system.

No it's an 'extra' Getty field, it should be in MediaManager but may not appear in the general interfaces, it's not a normal MediaManger date field.

Liz..apologies for not knowing much about MediaManger we didn't really have much to do with that end of things, we just got he value in the exported XML files.

Hi Finn,

OK done some further investigation, this is different from the last issue, but (my guess) is the one that is causing Justin the most frustration (the fact it only happens on repeat images also explains why it is seemingly intermittent).

It seems to be an issue with images that have been sent once before, in that when an image is re-sent Getty the associated image used to arrive as [ 01-Mar-2011_12_17_52/109499319JF002_2(4).JPG ] note the (4) in brackets before .jpg and so we would look on the server for a file with that file.

Now we seem to be getting a new format filename in the XML from Getty, which is the same in each case ie. 01-Mar-2011_12_17_52/109499319JF002_2.JPG regardless of how many times it is sent.

I have updated the code to take this into account *but* currently we have no images on the FTP server, I am not sure if this a larger bug at Getty's end or our clean up code.

Anyway, I have removed all the files form the sever, coudl you ask Justn to send over:

- A image that has never been sent before 
- An image that has (ie. 109499319JF002_2.JPG)

btw. I think when you search for the image in the CMS you'll need to use the CMS display name and not the filename.

Jamie

Hi Justin. In the morning please could you follow the process Jamie describes and we’ll see if we can get to the bottom of it? Please notify Jamie and co at support@kitsite.com when you do so and cc: me.

See below for more info on the issue in general...

Hi Justin/Finn,

The problem seems to be that we're are only being sent the XML files from Getty 

I'm seeing this error (below) from Getty (not us) I think this is saying that Getty can't find the image within it''s own system (this has nothing to do with the CMS or FTP server)

Previously when setting this up we dealt with Patrick Stewart <Patrick.Stewart@gettyimages.com> I'm not sure if he is still your contact there.

I Know Alex Brown had a similar issue with MediaManger previously and Patrick did suggest a solution to her (although I can't seem to find it in my email archive).

While I am happy to liaise with Getty on any technical questions (and do copy me in if you email them) we are obviously unable to fix any issues within MediaManager. 

My first suggestion would be to email them the error below (from their own system) and the knock-on effect that we are receiving the XML files without the associated images. 

* to be absolutely sure it isn't us deleting the images (and I am pretty sure we aren't) and to give Getty a chance to check what they are sending to the FTP server I am going to temporarily disable the feed. This means that what ever gets sent from MediaManger will just sit on the FTP server. 

Jamie

Documentation to describe how to deal with various contingencies, including:
- sister site going offline (redirecting traffic from main site)
- adding and removing splash pages
- putting up and taking down sorry pages
- managing config files (in Jan)
- managing rsync (in Jan)

Can I add to this:

Documenting the directories and paths for all the http daemons - including restart, startup and stop commands - is that part of the config files??
Quick update: this is all underway. We will deliver documentation around the same time that we switch to the staging servers (next week if we get through CAB this week).

Russ, we have created a new LOCOG Documentation help forum at http://postcms.zendesk.com/forums/347000-locog-documentation and added a new topic on the staging environment at http://postcms.zendesk.com/entries/443604-staging-environment

It contains information about adding and removing splash pages, rsync and config files.

It does not contain information about putting up and taking down sorry pages, which is a separate issue. 

It also does not contain information about stopping and restarting apache, but there is nothing specific to the staging environment about how this works.

comments.value: Can someone please remind me why we have it, rather than just having it be 'body' text?  It's causing frustration that we can't have links and add formatting into that area.

It was a plain text field that could be pulled though to other places, 
there are issues round truncating rich text due to opening and closing 
tags and links.

So the whole reasoning is that it /shouldn't have links in it.

But other than the news pages, where do we ever actually pull it through
to other places? We now have that field in meta-data which is where we
can put the text for the top-nav dropdown menu. And/or could the
strapline not be used for this type of purpose on most pages?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

Not sure where it is used, will need to double check where it is used (will be a cases of searching though all the templates and components and seign where the owrd 'summary' is used) 

So you want to turn the summary field into a 'rich text' field (ie. one with links) that only appears on the page and is never 'pulled though' if possible?

(btw. I think search may use it, which also truncate the text, just checking..)

The heart of the issue is that there are times when editors want to put links/images 'higher up' the page, and they can't. So any general way 'round this would be helpful. unless having links in straplines/summaries is 'bad' for SEO?


-----Original Message-----

The problem is it's harder to truncate text if it contains markup (we can't just truncate the string as we may chop off the end or

tag), so it's really nice to have a plain text field we can use for this. We could first try to strip out all markup of the string, but then we run the risk of text that says 'to see more click here' with no link? It probably is less idea for SEO and you certainly can't have links in your meta-description field. Maybe we could add a couple of hyperlink containers under the summary? or even a new field for text + links? Jamie

Hm - but where do we actually re-use that text? I can understand for
the strap-line area, but the summary?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

We use 'summary' in the search results for start, Stamen also use it on the map.

btw. it's not trivial  to tell where we use it as we don't store that info in the database, it's just a case of checking all the components / templates / other bits of code / external sites to check if any of them contain the word 'summary' and use it to pull back the summary in a way that will be affected if we allow links.

I can totally see why you want to make it rich text and while it's not as trivial as changing an attribute, it is something we can do without too much work (probably an hour or two's work with some testing). However going back the other way is harder as we have to drop links / markup (hence why I want us to be sure this is the correct thing to do . make sure you understand the implications of doing this).

The other reason I am reluctant to make a hasty change here is we won't fully know in advance all the consequences of doing this and so may need to fix other parts of the site that we're indirectly affected. For example if Stamen start complaining that the feed is sending them broken markup - we would check this early on, but it's an example of the sort of issues a change like this could cause.

So what am I suggesting / asking ?

- The change it self is fairly modest, but..

- Going backwards is more difficult once links and markup have been added, so while not a one way operation going backwards / reverting will have an additional cost.

- We may get some issues going forward, cause by doing this, that will need to be fixed, obviously if we leave things as they are we wont' have these issues ;-) so if we do make this change and then have to later on fix things like search or the Stamen feed we woudl see those issues as new work and not support.

I'm probably being overly cautious, but the point above is an important one (in terms of knock on effects being 'out of warranty' so to speak!)

Let me know how you want to progress (of feel free to have a quick phone chat)

Jamie

Ok - i am clearly going to need to give this more thought than i can spare at the moment. let's park it and leave it pending.

 _____
Marking as solved. Please re-open if it is an issue you want to revisit.

comments.value:
Bit of a peculiar one.

The my2012 platform doesn't come with a 'search' tool.  You can, however, integrate search boxes like google in it fairly easily (embedding standard google code? i know very little about such things). How embeddable/re-usable is the kitsite search tool that we've got on the .com site?  Clearly it would be ideal for us if the search would work across the two sites...but wasn't sure if that would actually be possible.  Thoughts?
Kieran, can I give this to you to respond to?

Hi Liz,

Sorry for the delay responding to this.

We could fairly easily re-use the search solution that we've used for the main site. The frontend component (i.e. the actual search box & results) would be the easiest part to implement. The bit that would involve most work on our part would be the indexing of the data - i.e. adding the my2012 pages to the search index.
Basically every time a page is created/changed/expired in the my2012 site, the search index needs to be notified accordingly.

This can happen in a number of ways:

1. The site can simply be periodically "scraped" - this is the least reliable way, and has the disadvantage that it is harder to reliably extract metadata - the search would essentially just be a free text search.

2. The my2012 content repository can be told to inform the search index whenever a 
page is published, or removed from the website, and to tell it which content is searchable (including things like dates & metadata). This is how the www.london2012.com website works.

3. If there is an API that we could use, we could periodically poll the my2012 repository to say "give me a list of content that has changed, including dates, metadata, etc.", and we can then update the repository accordingly.

It would be very useful to have some more information regarding the approximate size of the dataset that would be being searched, and also to know exactly what the my2012 backed / cms / repository is - in particular, whether it has an api, or is programmable/customizable in any way? If you have this information, please let me know - also, please ask if you have any more questions,

Kind regards,
Kieran

Thanks, Kieran! That was really helpful. At the moment I'm woefully
unaware of the back-end of the system, but my guess is that something
will be possible. There could be a LOT of pages that came about b/c of
all the user profiles, etc.

 

To clarify, your suggestions sound like they would work so that you
could search across *both* sites. Is that right? Would the process be
the same/different if we were to search only within the my2012.com
domain?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

To clarify, /either/ option would be possible.
From a performance p.o.v. we would /probably/ want to keep the two indexes separate, however without any idea of the size of the dataset, expected volumes, and expected user patterns (i.e. whether it will be a common use case to search across both sites), it's difficult to say precisely.
I think that as much as I can say right now is: Kitsite's backend search technology could certainly accomplish what you're looking for, but we'd need more details in order to give a realistic quote (which might - of course - include extra hardware as well as licensing). The biggest "don't know" is how we would get my2012 to push content into the search index - however, it's not a tremendously complex process, so I'm sure there would be a solution.
I hope this makes sense.
Kieran

Yes, it does! I'll try and get some more info for you, and get back to
you and then we can come up with a sensible solution.

 

Cheers, Kieran.

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________
closing.

comments.value: We have had a request to start creating weekly reports for user sign ups (in general, and by mailing list preference) plotted over time, so we can see where peaks come. As far as I am aware, we are not currently able to do this ourselves and it would require a report to be set up. Please can you advise how much work this would involve - and the cost? Thanks!

Hi Morag. Can I ask some questions to clarify this request please?

I think that what you want is the following:

 * For Kitsite to store historical data, recording the daily totals for:
     > Number of users.
     > Number of users subscribed to each mailing list.
     > For both of the above, we should probably store the total number, and the number of "Live" users (i.e. those who have clicked on their confirmation email)
     
 * Once we have the above, we can then generate reports for specific periods. For example, to generate a weekly report, we would compare today's values with the values from seven days ago.
 
I propose that you let us know what period you would like reports generated for, and we then run these on a schedule. For example you might tell me that you want: 
 * A weekly report that shows weekly totals for the last 6 months.
 * A daily report that shows daily totals for the 7 days.
 
An interface via which you can generate your own reports for bespoke periods, on an ad hoc basis would be more complicated, and thus take longer.

I would estimate that the simpler solution (i.e. running certain reports on a schedule) would take three days to implement.

The more complicated solution (i.e. an interface for you to generate reports on an ad hoc basis) would take longer. I can't say exactly without speaking to Janos (who is out of the office this week). I would estimate 5-6 days, but it /could/ be longer. I can investigate further if you decide that you require this solution.

I hope this makes sense?

Please contact me if you have any questions.

Kieran

Thanks for your response, Kieran.

I think I am looking for a cross between the two existing reports:

We currently get a daily report of historical sign-ups per day so we can see how many people have signed up each day since 2008.

We also get a daily report of how many people have signed up per mailing list over the past day only.

We would like a regular (weekly?) report of how many people have signed up to each mailing list going back to 2008, so that we can see where there are peaks, how marketing campaigns affect sign-ups etc.

Is this possible and do you have a sense of how much work would be involved?

Thanks!

Hi Morag,

Regarding the daily mailing list totals, we only starting storing the daily totals at the start of this year (January 2010), thus this report would be restricted to this period.

We do have daily totals for the "total number of users" going back to 2008 (in fact, all the way to 2004!). These are the totals that appear in the daily email (entitled "London 2012 registration report").

Turning the mailing list totals that we've been collecting this year into a weekly report, and listing all totals since the start of the year would take about 2 days.

I would suggest that the "total number of users" data probably isn't as much use as the "mailing list totals". However, if you wanted me to turn those daily emails into a csv file, that would be approximately 1 days work.

Once I know what you would like, I will be able to estimate a bit more accurately.

Kieran
Marking as high priority and pending.
changing to "open" otherwise it disappears off my radar

Hi, could you clarify which option you would like me to proceed with?

(copied from my previous comment)

Regarding the daily mailing list totals, we only starting storing the daily totals at the start of this year (January 2010), thus this report would be restricted to this period.

== option 1 ==

We do have daily totals for the "total number of users" going back to 2008 (in fact, all the way to 2004!). These are the totals that appear in the daily email (entitled "London 2012 registration report").

Turning the mailing list totals that we've been collecting this year into a weekly report, and listing all totals since the start of the year would take about 2 days.

== option 2 ==

I would suggest that the "total number of users" data probably isn't as much use as the "mailing list totals". However, if you wanted me to turn those daily emails into a csv file, that would be approximately 1 days work. 


My belief is that option 1 would be more meaningful, and thus more useful to you. 
You can - of course - have both if you like!

Kieran

Hi Morag, sorry to nudge you!
Could you let me know which of these I should proceed with please?
Many thanks,
Kieran.

I believe a new member of staff is starting at LOCOG next week whose brief it is to manage the user data. I think Morag wants to hold off on this while the new member of the team gets up to speed. You can probably expect a response from her shortly.

Just to update you on this:

We have a new emarketing manager on board, who is now the client for this information. AS a result I need to sit down with her to determine what kind of report she wants.

Will feedback as soon as I can!
Are you to look at this again?
was that aimed at me danny?
Closing.

comments.value: If it is required, we could redirect existing banners, but to do so will require liaising with ITS and BT to move the domain. Awaiting advice on whether there are enough banners in circulation to make it worthwhile to proceed.
Yeah, probably best to redirect. Don’t want weird empty gaps, even if it’s only a few hundred!

Makes sense, 

Just so your aware this is what needs to be done / who needs to do it:

1) Move banners [Kitsite]

We'll need to move all the old banners to a folder on the current www site (#we can do this now#)

2) Setup Virtual hosts [Kitsite]

We will eventually need to setup a new Virtual Host on web01-06 so that we can serve pages for www.london-2012.co.uk (ie. the old domain)
 
But we will need first need to make this change within the staging environment and test it by changing our local /etc/hosts file (sorry for the geekyness - basically we'll fake a DNS entry on one of our desktop machines so that when we type in www.london-2012.co.uk into a browser on that machine we'll go to the staging server and test everything works).

** the deployment of a new VirtualHost config section will require a CAB request **

3) Redirects [Kitsite]

We'll need to create some mod_rewrite (redirect) rules to redirect the old banner paths to the new panner paths on www.london2012.com (ie. the live server)

We'll first have to check these work on the staging server via the above method (editing /etc/hosts)

** the deployment of a the mod_rewrite rules will require a CAB request **

3) Domain names [ITS/BT]

ITS/BT will need to point the old www.london-2012.co.uk domain at the live web servers, in particular the load balancer 213.120.228.200 

This should be a trivial matter of updating a DNS A record

Once the domain has switched over the banners will no longer be tracked in the current manner and will instead be served from www.london2012.com

Jamie
Marked as high. Deadline: Feb 14.

I'm adding this here as I think there is a danger of stuff unnecessarily needing to be tested on the staging server, when it could easily be tested int eh CMS.

On the other hand we should probably suggest that we schedule in a day (or more) deployment and testing time for the SEO stuff where we halt *any syncing* for a few hours before/after we deploy the SEO changes and allow room / time for testing. This is obviously much more disruptive as it holds up editorial.

---

In terms of "populating templates on the staging server to allow for testing" the staging server will just sits between the CMS and the live web servers (web01-06) as part of the publication workflow. Under normal usage pages are created and published from the CMS to the staging server [as fully rendered HTML] from where they are replicated onto web01-06.

Think of it as a live[-1] server

All that will happen in this case is we will reconfigure the replication process so that the pages only get as far as the staging server (until they are signed off).

One thing to be aware of though is that the staging server (described above) sits directly in the main publication workflow, although we can stop replication of pages by section/path, pages outside of those section will still be published and if they contain links to pages within a section that has been 'held back' those links will result in page not found errors. 

Indeed as this site has hardly any server side (ie. PHP) functionality it may be preferable to preview and test the pages directly the CMS, this has the advantage that if the pages themselves aren't yet published then any pages that link to them will automatically have the relevant links suppressed. Therefore in many way this is a safer way to preview pages / sign off the site (the pages are rendered exactly as they would be when published with the advantage that links to them won't appear in pages that are published). Indeed this is how Morag and her team would normally sign off a site like this, which doesn't have server side components (and therefore doesn't actually need to be published to a web server in order to be tested).

A couple of points of clarification: 

- You mention "KitSite staging server" the staging server I am referring to above is a BT managed server (although we do have access to it).
- We also have our own development and staging servers, which I know Russ has accessed in the past (esp. when we are doing more 'risky' development, that may effect other areas of the site or CMS) but I assume by the trail of e-mails that this isn't the server that is begin refereed to.

I hope I haven't further added complication, but I wanted to clarify what is meant when the phrase 'staging server' is discussed as it can obviously give an impression of a 'snapshot of the site' that can be tested in complete isolation and then deployed in one click, this is not the case.

In many way for your requirements I would say previewing the pages in the CMS prior to publication is by far the safest and least troublesome way to test the site.

---
I think we have decided not to redirect the existing banners. Marking as solved.
